title: Will Noncitizens Pick New York’s Mayors?
sub_head: The City Council wants to let some 800,000 vote in local elections.
body:
New York has been a dynamic city for a long time, and immigrants are a big reason. Yet you can agree with that statement and still oppose a Democratic plan to let roughly 800,000 noncitizens vote in local elections for mayor, City Council, and so on. The council plans to consider a measure to that end on Dec. 9, and according to the New York Post it has enough support to pass.
The proposal, offered by Manhattan Councilman Ydanis Rodriguez, would permit voting by immigrants with either green cards or work authorization. The latter aren’t even necessarily long-term U.S. residents. “This is not about a favor, this is about taxation without representation,” Mr. Rodriguez said in September. “If people have a problem with this, then they should move to another town or another country that has not been built by immigrants.”
